sentence: She’s been so “nervenmässig”* lately, and we don’t feel like hearing her moan and groan again about all the beautiful china and lovely chairs she had to leave behind.
I can read German fairly well by now, except that I usually mumble the words instead of reading them silently to myself.
Father wants me to start reading books by Hebbel and other well-known German writers.
Father has taken the plays of Goethe and Schiller down from the big bookcase and is planning to read to me every evening.
This morning Miep told us that the furniture has been removed from the van Daans’ apartment on Zuider-Amstellaan.
Encouraged by Father’s good example, Mother pressed her prayer book into my hands.
The chimney hasn’t been swept in ages, so the room is bound to fill with smoke.
Mother is making him perspire in hopes of sweating out the fever.
Why is she making me act so religious and devout?
He’s covered with spots and has a high temperature.
They certainly sound beautiful, but they mean very little to me.
I read a few prayers in German, just to be polite.
Tomorrow we’re going to light the stove for the first time.
Let’s hope the thing draws!
Just think, we can’t even call a doctor!
We’ve started off with Don Carlos.
What’s the good of grumbling about it now?
It looks like measles.
We had to abandon most of our nice things too.
We haven’t told Mrs. van D. yet.
Father’s sick.
I’m very worried.
But that’ll pass.
